elements.content: Five 1–3D cadmium­(II) coordination polymers, namely, [Cd­(HL)­(DMF)] n (1), [Cd4(HL)4(H2O)6] n (2), [Cd­(HL)­(phen)] n (3), [Cd2(HL)2(bpy)] n (4), and {[Cd3(HL)3(pbim)2]·H2O} n (5), have been synthesized and fully characterized [H3L = 2-(5-bromo-pyridin-3-yl)-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid, DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide, phen = 1,10-phenanthroline, bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine, and pbim = 1,1′-(5-methyl-1,3-phenylene)­bis­(1H-imidazole)]. In those complexes, the doubly deprotonated H3L ligands and CdII ions display versatile coordination modes to construct various structures with interesting topologies. Complex 1 is a 2D helical structure with (4·82) topology built up from 3-connected (HL)2– and CdII nodes. Complex 2 containing (HL)2–-bridged tetranuclear CdII subunits is a 3D helical structure where both (HL)2– and CdII adopt three coordination modes to form a rare 3-connected network with (5·8·12)2(5·12·16)2(5·82)­(82·12) topology. Substituting the smaller terminal ligands DMF and water with the larger terminal ligand phen, (HL)2– ligands only use their imidazoledicarboxylate groups to bis-chelate CdII into a chain structure of 3. Complex 4 is a (3,4)-connected 3D network with (4·82)­(4·82·103) topology built up from the (HL)2–-bridged (4,82) mesolayer observed in 1 being further linked by rodlike bpy bridges replacing terminal ligand DMF. Complex 5 consists of (HL)2–- and pbim-bridged macrocycle chains and is a (3,4)-connected 2D novel network with (3·4·8)2(3·4·5·82·9)2(32·82·92) topology. As expected, the strongly bis-chelating coordination mode μ-kN,O:kN′,O′ of the imidazoledicarboxylate of (HL)2– absolutely dominates the assemblies with CdII in those complexes. Intriguingly, the additional ligands, such as smaller terminal ligands water and DMF, larger planar terminal ligand phen, as well as rodlike and V-shaped bridges bpy and pbim, exert obvious influence on the coordination modes of ligands (HL)2– and the resulting architectures. Clearly, larger terminal and bridging ligands phen and pbim could limit the coordination of the pyridyl of (HL)2– through steric hindrance. Meanwhile, the solid-state photoluminescence of those compounds at room temperature was also investigated, and the results indicate that their emissions are significantly influenced by the additional ligands incorporating into the networks.

elements.content: Five 1−3D cadmium­(II) coordination polymers with architectural diversities and interesting topologies, in which the doubly deprotonated 2-(5-bromo-pyridin-3-yl)-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid and CdII display versatile coordination modes, have been synthesized and structurally determined. Intriguingly, the additional ligands exert obvious influence not only on the coordination modes of the main ligand but also on the architectures and photoluminescence properties of the resulting complexes.
elements.clean_text: Five 1-3D cadmium(II) coordination polymers with architectural diversities and interesting topologies, in which the doubly deprotonated 2-(5-bromo-pyridin-3-yl)-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid and CdII display versatile coordination modes, have been synthesized and structurally determined. Intriguingly, the additional ligands exert obvious influence not only on the coordination modes of the main ligand but also on the architectures and photoluminescence properties of the resulting complexes.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) as a new class of multifunctional materials have attracted significant recent attention and have been extensively explored for potential applications in gas storage and separation, fluorescence, heterogeneous catalysis, sensing, magnetism, drug delivery, and so forth. In the past decades, 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (H3IDC) as a rigid and multifunctional bridge has been extensively used to construct MOFs. Those results disclosed that the H3IDC ligand showed intriguing versatility of coordination modes but usually adopted the dominating bis-chelating coordination mode μ-kN,O:kN′,O′ to direct the construction of MOFs. Of further interest is functionalized H3IDC at its 2-positon with diverse substituents such as methyl, ethyl, or pyridyl, and based on this modification, a series of H3IDC derivatives have been designed, synthesized, and used to construct MOFs with various metal ions by our and other groups. Interestingly, it was found that those derivatives not only carried forward the merits such as coordination direction and diversity from H3IDC but also added tunable factors such as additional coordination sites and structural constraint from the substituents, which could be further used to control the assemblies of MOFs. Furthermore, the functionalization at the 2-positon of H3IDC could endow the resulting derivatives and MOFs with unique properties. Accordingly, the derivatives of H3IDC have become a class of first-rank ligands for constructing MOFs with abundant diversities in architectures and topologies as well, but their coordination chemistry remains largely unexplored.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as a new class of multifunctional materials have attracted significant recent attention and have been extensively explored for potential applications in gas storage and separation, fluorescence, heterogeneous catalysis, sensing, magnetism, drug delivery, and so forth. In the past decades, 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid (H3IDC) as a rigid and multifunctional bridge has been extensively used to construct MOFs. Those results disclosed that the H3IDC ligand showed intriguing versatility of coordination modes but usually adopted the dominating bis-chelating coordination mode μ-kN,O:kN',O' to direct the construction of MOFs. Of further interest is functionalized H3IDC at its 2-positon with diverse substituents such as methyl, ethyl, or pyridyl, and based on this modification, a series of H3IDC derivatives have been designed, synthesized, and used to construct MOFs with various metal ions by our and other groups. Interestingly, it was found that those derivatives not only carried forward the merits such as coordination direction and diversity from H3IDC but also added tunable factors such as additional coordination sites and structural constraint from the substituents, which could be further used to control the assemblies of MOFs. Furthermore, the functionalization at the 2-positon of H3IDC could endow the resulting derivatives and MOFs with unique properties. Accordingly, the derivatives of H3IDC have become a class of first-rank ligands for constructing MOFs with abundant diversities in architectures and topologies as well, but their coordination chemistry remains largely unexplored.

elements.content: In this context, as well as further pursuing our work in this area, we designed and synthesized 2-(5-bromo-pyridin-3-yl)-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid (H3L), another compound analogous to our previously reported pyridyl-containing H3IDC derivatives (). In contrast with 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid ligand, the additional halogen atom Br in H3L not only provides halogen-related interactions to extend the dimensions of the resulting MOFs but also influences the photoelectric properties and chemical environment of the MOFs, which has become quite attractive in recent crystal engineering. In this paper, cadmium­(II) ion, one of currently used metal ions for the construction of functional MOFs, has been selected as a metal center to incorporate into our H3L-based MOFs due to its labile coordination number and the interesting fluorescence of its complexes. As is well-known, the combination of different ligands may result in greater tunability than that present with only a single ligand to construct MOFs, and thus, a series of N-heterocyclic ligands such as planar chelating ligand 1,10-phenanthroline (phen), rodlike bridge 4,4′-bipyridine (bpy), and V-shaped bridge 1,1′-(5-methyl-1,3-phenylene)­bis­(1H-imidazole) (pbim) are chosen as auxiliary ligands in our present work (). By doing so, we hope to modulate the structures and properties of H3L-based Cd–MOFs through the different structure types and coordination tendencies of the additional ligands and to further understand the assembly principles in a mixed ligand system as well. We report herein the syntheses, structural analysis, thermal stability, and photoluminescent properties of five cadmium­(II) complexes, namely, [Cd­(HL)­(DMF)] n (1), [Cd4(HL)4(H2O)6] n (2), [Cd­(HL)­(phen)] n (3), [Cd2(HL)2(bpy)] n (4), and {[Cd3(HL)3(pbim)2]·H2O} n (5) (DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide). Interestingly, changing the substituent in imidazole-based dicarboxylic ligands and using auxiliary ligands lead to architectural diversity of the Cd–MOFs.

elements.content: All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade or better and used without further purification. The ligand H3L was prepared by following the reported procedure for the synthesis of 2-(pyridin-4-yl)-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid, and the detailed synthesis and characterization data were provided in the Supporting Information. Element analyses were performed with a Carlo-Erba 1106 elemental analyzer. IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded on a Nicolet NEXUS 470 FT-IR spectrophotometer from 400 to 4000 cm–1. Thermal analysis curves were scanned from 30 to 800 °C under air on a STA 409 PC thermal analyzer. The solid-state fluorescent spectra were determined at room temperature on a Hitachi F-4500 fluorophotometer with a xenon arc lamp as light source. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the samples were recorded by a RIGAKU-DMAX2500 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Procedures

All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade or better and used without further purification. The ligand H3L was prepared by following the reported procedure for the synthesis of 2-(pyridin-4-yl)-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid, and the detailed synthesis and characterization data were provided in the Supporting Information. Element analyses were performed with a Carlo-Erba 1106 elemental analyzer. IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded on a Nicolet NEXUS 470 FT-IR spectrophotometer from 400 to 4000 cm-1. Thermal analysis curves were scanned from 30 to 800 °C under air on a STA 409 PC thermal analyzer. The solid-state fluorescent spectra were determined at room temperature on a Hitachi F-4500 fluorophotometer with a xenon arc lamp as light source. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the samples were recorded by a RIGAKU-DMAX2500 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation.

elements.content: A mixture of CdSO4·8H2O (0.0176 g, 0.05 mmol), H3L (0.0156 g, 0.05 mmol), NaOH (0.0040 g, 0.1 mmol), methanol (6 mL), and DMF (2 mL) was stirred for 30 min at room temperature and then filtered. Upon evaporating the filtrate at room temperature without disturbance for 4 weeks, colorless block crystals were obtained, washed with methanol, and dried in air, resulting in 34% yield (based on Cd). Anal. Calcd for C13H11BrCdN4O5 (%): C, 31.51; H, 2.24; N, 11.31. Found: C, 31.64; H, 2.26; N, 11.25. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3445 (br), 1651 (s), 1580 (vs), 1474 (m), 1381 (m), 1010 (m), 895 (m), 864 (m), 681 (w), 543 (w).

elements.content: On an Oxford diffractometer equipped with a CCD detector, single-crystal X-ray data were collected at 293(2) K using graphite-monochromated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) and Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) for 1–2 and 3–5, respectively. Absorption corrections were applied by using the multiscan program SADABS. Structural solutions and full-matrix least-squares refinements based on F 2 were performed with the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 program packages, respectively. All of the nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters during the final cycles. The H atoms attached to C were generated geometrically, whereas the H atoms attached to O were located from different Fourier maps and treated as idealized contributions. The crystal and refinement data are collected in , and the selected bond distances and angles are given in Table S1.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structure Determination and Structure Refinement

On an Oxford diffractometer equipped with a CCD detector, single-crystal X-ray data were collected at 293(2) K using graphite-monochromated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) and Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) for 1-2 and 3-5, respectively. Absorption corrections were applied by using the multiscan program SADABS. Structural solutions and full-matrix least-squares refinements based on F 2 were performed with the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 program packages, respectively. All of the nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters during the final cycles. The H atoms attached to C were generated geometrically, whereas the H atoms attached to O were located from different Fourier maps and treated as idealized contributions. The crystal and refinement data are collected in , and the selected bond distances and angles are given in Table S1.

In the preparation of compounds 1–5, NaOH was used for deprotonation with a 2:1 molar ratio of NaOH and H3L. In this basicity, two protons were removed from every H3L ligand, and each H3L ligand acts as a divalent anion (HL)2–. In combination with the following structural analysis, it can be observed that the proton dissociation from ligand H3L occurred in the imidazole group and one carboxyl. However, making the solution more alkali for further deprotonation, such as with a 3:1 molar ratio of NaOH and H3L, only resulted in unidentified precipitates. As the ratios of metal CdII and ligand H3L varied from 1:1 to 1.5:1 or to 2:1 in combination with the suitable modification of basicity, unidentified precipitates were also obtained. Remarkably, those hydro/solvothermal reaction systems are very sensitive to temperature with irregular polycrystals obtained at lower temperatures such as 140 or 145 °C, whereas at higher temperatures such as 160 °C, only precipitates are obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and General Characterization of Compounds 1-5 

In the preparation of compounds 1-5, NaOH was used for deprotonation with a 2:1 molar ratio of NaOH and H3L. In this basicity, two protons were removed from every H3L ligand, and each H3L ligand acts as a divalent anion (HL)2-. In combination with the following structural analysis, it can be observed that the proton dissociation from ligand H3L occurred in the imidazole group and one carboxyl. However, making the solution more alkali for further deprotonation, such as with a 3:1 molar ratio of NaOH and H3L, only resulted in unidentified precipitates. As the ratios of metal CdII and ligand H3L varied from 1:1 to 1.5:1 or to 2:1 in combination with the suitable modification of basicity, unidentified precipitates were also obtained. Remarkably, those hydro/solvothermal reaction systems are very sensitive to temperature with irregular polycrystals obtained at lower temperatures such as 140 or 145 °C, whereas at higher temperatures such as 160 °C,  only precipitates are obtained.

elements.content: As for the synthesis methods, compound 1 was obtained through traditional evaporation of the resulting methanol/DMF reaction solution, whereas the others were hydro/solvothermally synthesized at 150 °C by changing solvents from water to water/methanol mixtures. Notably, 3–5 were obtained in the presence of the auxiliary ligands phen, bpy, and pbim, respectively.
elements.clean_text: As for the synthesis methods, compound 1 was obtained through traditional evaporation of the resulting methanol/DMF reaction solution, whereas the others were hydro/solvothermally synthesized at 150 °C by changing solvents from water to water/methanol mixtures. Notably, 3-5 were obtained in the presence of the auxiliary ligands phen, bpy, and pbim, respectively.

elements.content: The chemical formulas of these complexes have been confirmed by satisfactory elemental analysis and X-ray diffraction. In the IR spectra of 1–5, the strong and broad absorption bands in a range of 3412–3445 cm–1 may be assigned to the characteristic peaks of the νO–H stretching frequencies of the undeprotonated carboxyl in ligand (HL)2– and water molecules, respectively. Five complexes exhibit strong characteristic absorptions around 1536–1613 cm–1 [νas(COO–)] and 1382–1479 cm–1 [νs(COO−)], respectively. As for the strong absorption band centered at 1651 cm–1 in the IR spectrum of 1, it may be attributed to the νco stretching frequency of the coordinated DMF.
elements.clean_text: The chemical formulas of these complexes have been confirmed by satisfactory elemental analysis and X-ray diffraction. In the IR spectra of 1-5, the strong and broad absorption bands in a range of 3412-3445 cm-1 may be assigned to the characteristic peaks of the νO-H stretching frequencies of the undeprotonated carboxyl in ligand (HL)2- and water molecules, respectively. Five complexes exhibit strong characteristic absorptions around 1536-1613 cm-1 [νas(COO-)] and 1382-1479 cm-1 [νs(COO-)], respectively. As for the strong absorption band centered at 1651 cm-1 in the IR spectrum of 1, it may be attributed to the νco stretching frequency of the coordinated DMF.

elements.content: The phase purities of the as-synthesized crystalline products 1–5 were determined by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements. As shown in Figures S1–5, the calculated PXRD patterns from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data are in good agreement with the observed ones, indicating phase purity of the polycrystalline samples. Thermal stability of these complexes was investigated by the TGA technique (Figure S6). The TGA curves of 1 and 2 are similar. They began to undergo weight losses at 125 and 120 °C, respectively. With heating, they suffered continuous weight losses until reaching 770 and 630 °C, respectively. The resulting residues of 26.34% for 1 and 28.45% for 2 are presumed to be CdO (calcd 25.91 and 28.57% for 1 and 2, respectively). Compounds 3 and 4 are stable up to 327 and 267 °C, respectively. As overtaken by their heat-resistant temperatures, the samples of 3 and 4 suffered continuous decomposition processes. In the crucibles, the remains of 22.07% for 3 and 24.73% for 4 may be CdO (calcd 22.49 and 25.65% for 3 and 4, respectively). The dehydration process of 5 occurred from 85 to 135 °C, and a further continuous weight loss followed from 178 to 715 °C with the resulting residue of 21.79% perhaps being CdO (calcd 22.21%).

With heating, they suffered continuous weight losses until reaching 770 and 630 °C, respectively. The resulting residues of 26.34% for 1 and 28.45% for 2 are presumed to be CdO (calcd 25.91 and 28.57% for 1 and 2, respectively). Compounds 3 and 4 are stable up to 327 and 267 °C, respectively. As overtaken by their heat-resistant temperatures, the samples of 3 and 4 suffered continuous decomposition processes. In the crucibles, the remains of 22.07% for 3 and 24.73% for 4 may be CdO (calcd 22.49 and 25.65% for 3 and 4, respectively). The dehydration process of 5 occurred from 85 to 135 °C, and a further continuous weight loss followed from 178 to 715 °C with the resulting residue of 21.79% perhaps being CdO (calcd 22.21%).

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic C2/c space group, and its asymmetrical unit contains one CdII, one (HL)2–, and one DMF molecule. As shown in , the CdII center is coordinated with three N and two O atoms from three individual (HL)2– ligands and one O atom from a DMF molecule, forming a sharply distorted coordination octahedron with the cis and trans bond angle ranges of 72.4(1)–112.4(2)° and 149.6(2)–168.2(1)°, respectively. In the coordination octahedron, two of the three (HL)2– ligands cis-chelate the CdII center with the N and O atoms from their imidazoledicarboxylate groups, and the dihedral angle between the two chelating rings is 79.9(2)°. Cd–N and Cd–O distances cover a range of 2.280(4)–2.346(4) Å, being comparable to our reported values in the cadmium­(II) complexes of H3IDC analogues.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Analysis and Discussion

[Cd(HL)(DMF)] n  (1)

Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic C2/c space group, and its asymmetrical unit contains one CdII, one (HL)2-, and one DMF molecule. As shown in , the CdII center is coordinated with three N and two O atoms from three individual (HL)2- ligands and one O atom from a DMF molecule, forming a sharply distorted coordination octahedron with the cis and trans bond angle ranges of 72.4(1)-112.4(2)° and 149.6(2)-168.2(1)°, respectively. In the coordination octahedron, two of the three (HL)2- ligands cis-chelate the CdII center with the N and O atoms from their imidazoledicarboxylate groups, and the dihedral angle between the two chelating rings is 79.9(2)°. Cd-N and Cd-O distances cover a range of 2.280(4)-2.346(4) Å, being comparable to our reported values in the cadmium(II) complexes of H3IDC analogues.

elements.content: ORTEP view of the coordination environment of the CdII atom in 1 with thermal ellipsoids at the 50% probability level (hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity). Symmetry code: (A) 1/2 – x, 1/2 – y, 1 – z; (B) x, −y, −1/2 + z.
elements.clean_text: 1  ORTEP view of the coordination environment of the CdII atom in 1 with thermal ellipsoids at the 50% probability level (hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity). Symmetry code: (A) 1/2 - x, 1/2 - y, 1 - z; (B) x, -y, -1/2 + z.

elements.content: In 1, each (HL)2– ligand adopts a μ3-kN,O:kN′,O′:kN″ coordination mode with its imidazoledicarboxylate chelating two CdII and its pyridyl bonding another CdII. The resulting dihedral angle between the imidazole and pyridyl groups of (HL)2– is 37.0(3)°, which contrasts with the almost coplanar conformer of H3L found in its adduct of bpy (Figure S7). Every CdII in 1 also acts as a 3-connector ligating with three (HL)2– ligands. As displayed in a, (HL)2– ligands in bis-N,O-chelating modes bridge CdII centers into b axially extended left- and right-handed helixes with the 21 helical pitches being 8.761(1) Å, and these adjacent left- and right-handed helixes are further linked together through the coordination of the pyridyl groups of (HL)2– ligands. Consequently, it forms a 3-connected mesolayer with (4·82) topology (b). Finally, these layers stack up along the a axis through interlayered Br···Ocarboxyl interactions (3.002(5) Å), forming a 3D supramolecular framework (Figure S8).
elements.clean_text: In 1, each (HL)2- ligand adopts a μ3-kN,O:kN',O':kN" coordination mode with its imidazoledicarboxylate chelating two CdII and its pyridyl bonding another CdII. The resulting dihedral angle between the imidazole and pyridyl groups of (HL)2- is 37.0(3)°, which contrasts with the almost coplanar conformer of H3L found in its adduct of bpy (Figure S7). Every CdII in 1 also acts as a 3-connector ligating with three (HL)2- ligands. As displayed in a, (HL)2- ligands in bis-N,O-chelating modes bridge CdII centers into b axially extended left- and right-handed helixes with the 21 helical pitches being 8.761(1) Å, and these adjacent left- and right-handed helixes are further linked together through the coordination of the pyridyl groups of (HL)2- ligands. Consequently, it forms a 3-connected mesolayer with (4⋅82) topology (b). Finally, these layers stack up along the a axis through interlayered Br⋅⋅⋅Ocarboxyl interactions (3.002(5) Å), forming a 3D supramolecular framework (Figure S8).

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21 /c space group, and its asymmetrical unit contains four CdII, four (HL)2–, and six coordinated H2O. The four crystallographically independent CdII are bridged by the four crystallographically independent (HL)2– to form a tetranuclear [Cd4(HL)4] subunit (Figure S9). As shown in , CdII centers and (HL)2– ligands in 2 have three kinds of coordination geometries and modes, respectively. Cd1 and Cd3 adopt distorted pentagonal bipyramid geometries with three N and two O atoms from two trans-chelating imidazoledicarboxylates and one pyridyl of three individual (HL)2– ligands in the equatorial plane and two O atoms from water molecules at the apical sites (the bond lengths of Cd–N and Cd–O range from 2.334(5) to 2.453(5) Å). Cd2 is in a sharply distorted octahedron with two N and two O atoms from two trans-chelating imidazoledicarboxylates of two (HL)2– ligands in the equatorial plane and two O atoms from one water molecule and one bridging carboxylate of another (HL)2– ligand at the apical sites (the bond lengths of Cd–N and Cd–O range from 2.283(4) to 2.360(7) Å). Cd4 is five-coordinated by two N and three O atoms from two trans-chelating imidazoledicarboxylates of two (HL)2– ligands and a water molecule and thereby form a distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry with the three coordinated O atoms in the equatorial plane and the two N atoms at the apical sites (the bond lengths of Cd–N and Cd–O range from 2.184(10) to 2.278(5) Å). Notably, the bond lengths of Cd–N and Cd–O in 2 comparatively shorten with the decrease of coordination number of CdII ions from 7 to 5 but fall in the normal ranges. As for the four crystallographically independent (HL)2– ligands, two of them adopt μ3-kN,O:kN′,O′:kN″ coordination mode observed in 1 to connect Cd1, Cd3 (Cd3E), and Cd4 (Cd4C), one adopts μ3-kN,O:kN′,O′:kO″ coordination mode to bridge Cd1, Cd2, and Cd2D, and the other adopts μ-kN,O:kN′,O′ coordination mode to chelate Cd2 and Cd3 (). In 2, the four crystallographically independent (HL)2– ligands vary the dihedral angles between their imidazole and pyridyl groups from 21.1(3) to 32.7(3)°, matching the coordination requirements in different conformers.
elements.clean_text:
[Cd4(HL)4(H2O)6] n  (2)

Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21 /c space group, and its asymmetrical unit contains four CdII, four (HL)2-, and six coordinated H2O. The four crystallographically independent CdII are bridged by the four crystallographically independent (HL)2- to form a tetranuclear [Cd4(HL)4] subunit (Figure S9). As shown in , CdII centers and (HL)2- ligands in 2 have three kinds of coordination geometries and modes, respectively. Cd1 and Cd3 adopt distorted pentagonal bipyramid geometries with three N and two O atoms from two trans-chelating imidazoledicarboxylates and one pyridyl of three individual (HL)2- ligands in the equatorial plane and two O atoms from water molecules at the apical sites (the bond lengths of Cd-N and Cd-O range from 2.334(5) to 2.453(5) Å). Cd2 is in a sharply distorted octahedron with two N and two O atoms from two trans-chelating imidazoledicarboxylates of two (HL)2- ligands in the equatorial plane and two O atoms from one water molecule and one bridging carboxylate of another (HL)2- ligand at the apical sites (the bond lengths of Cd-N and Cd-O range from 2.283(4) to 2.360(7) Å). Cd4 is five-coordinated by two N and three O atoms from two trans-chelating imidazoledicarboxylates of two (HL)2- ligands and a water molecule and thereby form a distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry with the three coordinated O atoms in the equatorial plane and the two N atoms at the apical sites (the bond lengths of Cd-N and Cd-O range from 2.184(10) to 2.278(5) Å). Notably, the bond lengths of Cd-N and Cd-O in 2 comparatively shorten with the decrease of coordination number of CdII ions from 7 to 5 but fall in the normal ranges. As for the four crystallographically independent (HL)2- ligands, two of them adopt μ3-kN,O:kN',O':kN" coordination mode observed in 1 to connect Cd1, Cd3 (Cd3E), and Cd4 (Cd4C), one adopts μ3-kN,O:kN',O':kO" coordination mode to bridge Cd1, Cd2, and Cd2D, and the other adopts μ-kN,O:kN',O' coordination mode to chelate Cd2 and Cd3 (). In 2, the four crystallographically independent (HL)2- ligands vary the dihedral angles between their imidazole and pyridyl groups from 21.1(3) to 32.7(3)°, matching the coordination requirements in different conformers.

elements.content: As shown in a, the Cd1 and Cd2 in adjacent [Cd4(HL)4] subunits are bis-chelated by the ligands (HL)2– in the μ3-kN,O:kN′,O′:kO″ coordination mode. As a result, those subunits are bridged into b axially extended left- and right-handed helixes with the 21 helical pitches being 8.2845(1) Å. The adjacent left- and right-handed helixes are further linked together along the c axis through the ligands (HL)2– in the μ3-kN,O:kN′,O′:kN″ coordination mode bis-chelating with the Cd1 and Cd4 of adjacent helixes, which results in a mesolayer (b). Notably, the ligands (HL)2–, which bridge left- and right-handed helixes into mesolayers, further use their Npyridyl to ligate Cd3 nodes in adjacent layers and finally form a complicated 3D framework (a). In 2, three-fourths of CdII centers and (HL)2– ligands act as 3-connected nodes, whereas the other one-fourth just act as connections. The molar ratio of those nodes is 2:2:1:1, and thus, the resulting structure can be simplified as a rare 3-connected network with a Schläfli symbol of (5·6·12)2(5·122)2(62·12)­(5·62) (b).

The adjacent left- and right-handed helixes are further linked together along the c axis through the ligands (HL)2- in the μ3-kN,O:kN',O':kN" coordination mode bis-chelating with the Cd1 and Cd4 of adjacent helixes, which results in a mesolayer (b). Notably, the ligands (HL)2-, which bridge left- and right-handed helixes into mesolayers, further use their Npyridyl to ligate Cd3 nodes in adjacent layers and finally form a complicated 3D framework (a). elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21 /c space group, and its asymmetrical unit contains one CdII, one (HL)2–, and one phen. The CdII center in 3 is located in a N4O2 coordination octahedron cis-chelated by two imidazoledicarboxylates of two (HL)2– ligands and one phen molecule (). The bond lengths of Cd–N and Cd–O range from 2.213(3) to 2.438(3) Å, whereas the cis- and trans-bond angles range from 69.6(1) to 159.8(1)°, indicating a sharp distortion of the coordination geometry from an ideal octahedron. In 3, the dihedral angle between the imidazole and pyridyl groups of the (HL)2– ligand is 37.3(2)°, which is very similar to that in 1. Notably, the introduction of the planar chelating ligand phen not only edges out the coordination of the smaller solvent molecules but limits the dimension of the resulting polymer and coordination number of (HL)2– ligands as well. Because of the stronger chelation and steric hindrance of auxiliary phen ligands, (HL)2– ligands in 3 only use their imidazoledicarboxylates to bis-chelate CdII centers and thereby form a c axially extended zigzag polymeric chain (). Their pyridyls do not participate in further coordination with CdII. In the chain structure, every chelating phen leads to one (HL)2– ligand such that doubly intrachain π···π interactions occur between the two ligands (Figure S10; the centroid-to-centroid distance between the pyridyl ring N5C18C19C20C21C22 of phen and the imidazole ring N1AC2AC3AN2AC21C5A of (HL)2– is 3.798(2) Å; the centroid-to-centroid distance between the pyridyl ring N4C11C12C13C14C17 of phen and the pyridyl ring C6AC7AC8AC9AN3AC10A of (HL)2– is 3.548(3) Å; A = x, 1/2 – y, −1/2 + z). The neighboring polymeric chains connect with each other through interchain Br···Ocarboxyl interactions (3.041(3) Å), resulting in a 2D supramolecular framework (Figure S11).

elements.content: Compound 4 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Pccn space group, and its asymmetrical unit contains one CdII, one (HL)2–, and one-half bpy molecule. As shown in , the CdII center is in a sharply distorted N4O2 octahedron ligated by two N and two O atoms from two cis-chelating imidazoledicarboxylates of two (HL)2– ligands and two other N atoms from the pyridyls of another (HL)2– ligand and one bpy molecule, respectively. The dihedral angle between the two chelating rings is 69.3(3)°, which is smaller than that observed in 1. The bond distances and bond angles are comparable with those found in the octahedral CdII of 1.

elements.content: Ligands (HL)2– in 4 also adopt μ3-kN,O:kN′,O′:kN″ coordination mode and link CdII centers into a mesolayer with the (4,82) topology as observed in 1 (). The dihedral angle between the imidazole and pyridyl groups of ligand (HL)2– is 38.1(3)°, which is very similar to those found in 1 and 3. In 4, these a axially extended left- and right-handed helixes formed by the bis-N,O-chelation of the imidazoledicarboxylates with CdII centers have a shorter 21 helical pitch of 7.8467(4) Å. Along the c axis, adjacent heterochiral helixes further tie together through the further coordination of the pyridyls of (HL)2– ligands with CdII nodes to form the mesolayers. Uniquely, the rigid rodlike ancillary ligand bpy further bridges CdII centers from adjacent homochiral helixes in different mesolayers to then form a 3D coordination polymer (). In a sense, the formation of 4 can be regarded as the in situ replacement of the terminal ligand DMF in 1 by the bridge bpy. Topologically, the 3D structure of 4 can be simplified as a (3,4)-connected network with the Schläfli symbol (4·82)­(4·82·103), where (HL)2– ligands and CdII centers act as 3- and 4-connected nodes, respectively (b).

elements.content: Compound 5 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group, and its asymmetrical unit consists of three CdII, three (HL)2–, two pbim, and two lattice H2O. As shown in , the three crystallographically independent CdII all adopt six-coordinated distorted octahedral geometries. The Cd1 and Cd3 in N3O3 octahedra are coordinated by two N and two O atoms from two cis-chelating imidazoledicarboxylates of two (HL)2– ligands, one O from the carboxylate of another (HL)2– ligand, and one N atom from a pbim molecule. Cd2 as the interval of Cd1 and Cd3 is in a N4O2 octahedron ligated by two N and two O atoms from two cis-chelating imidazoledicarboxylates of two (HL)2– ligands and another two N atoms from two pbim molecules. Every CdII center in 5 is cis-chelated by two (HL)2– ligands like that found in 1, but the dihedral angles between two chelating rings ranging from 63.8(3) to 69.5(3)° are smaller than that of 79.9(2)° in 1 and close to that in 3. The Cd–N and Cd–O distances cover a normal range of 2.251(7)–2.485(6) Å. The three crystallographically independent (HL)2– ligands in 5 adopt two kinds of coordination modes: one adopting μ-kN,O:kN′,O′ coordination mode just like that observed in 3 and the other two adopting μ3-kN,O:kN′,O′:kO′ coordination mode. As observed in 3, the pyridyls of all (HL)2– ligands in 5 do not participate in further coordination with CdII. For the three crystallographically independent (HL)2– ligands, the dihedral angles between their imidazole and pyridyl groups are 30.8(5), 44.8(5), and 41.1(5)°, respectively. The two crystallographically independent pbim ligands bridge Cd1 and Cd2 or Cd2 and Cd3, respectively, and the dihedral angles between their two imidazole rings are 41.9(6) and 33.9(6)°, respectively.

elements.content: Complex 5 features a 2D network consisting of polymeric macrocycle chains (a). As shown in b, there are two kinds of similar trinuclear rings: one formed by a (HL)2– ligand in μ3-kN,O:kN′,O′:kO′ coordination mode connecting Cd1, Cd1B, and Cd2 and a pbim bridging Cd1 and Cd2, and the other formed by another (HL)2– ligand in μ3-kN,O:kN′,O′:kO′ coordination mode connecting Cd2, Cd3, and Cd3C and another pbim bridging Cd2 and Cd3C. Through sharing with the Cd2 nodes and the μ-Ocarboxylic-bridging binuclear [(μ-O)2(Cd3)2] or [(μ-O)2(Cd1)2] units, those trinuclear rings are linked into the macrocyclic chain structure. The ligands (HL)2– in the μ-kN,O:kN′,O′ coordination mode bis-chelate with Cd1 and Cd3 atoms of adjacent chains to form the 2D network. Topologically, two-thirds of (HL)2– ligands act as 3-connected nodes, whereas the other one-third and all pbim ligands just act as connectors, and all CdII centers can be regarded as 4-connected nodes. In this way, the structure of 5 can be rationalized as a (3,4)-connected net. The molar ratio of those three kinds of nodes is 2:2:1. Thus, the framework of 5 is symbolized as a very novel (3·4·8)2(3·4·5·82·9)2(32·82·92) network (). The crystal packing analysis shows that those 2D frameworks interdigitate together along the b axis through interlayered π···π interactions between pbim molecules of adjacent layers (Figure S12; the centroid-to-centroid distance between the imidazole and phenylene rings of pbim ligands is 3.649(6) Å).

elements.content: The solid-state luminescent properties of cadmium­(II) polymers 1–5 were investigated at room temperature (the phase purity was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction as shown in Figures S1–5). Compounds 1–5 all exhibited one emission band centered at 421, 448, 449, 444, and 400 nm upon excitation at 366, 365, 383, 362, and 345 nm, respectively (). In combination with the emission spectra of free ligands H3L, phen, bpy, and pbim (Figures S13 and S14), the emission bands of 1–5 that slightly blue- or red-shift from the 425 nm emission of free ligand H3L can be mainly attributed to the intraligand π–π* transitions of (HL)2– ligands, which can be compared with those emissions reported for cadmium­(II) complexes with other N-donor ligands. The differences in the excitation and emission energies for 1–5 are dependent on metal–ligand perturbations and thereby on the coordination geometries of CdII in every compound. Additionally, the relatively broad emission bands for 3–5 indicate some contribution from the intraligand π–π* transitions of the auxiliary ligands phen, bpy, and pbim. On the whole, complexes 1–5 exhibit stronger emission intensities compared to the emission peak of free ligand H3L. The intensity increase of the luminescence for these complexes may be attributed to the chelation of (HL)2– with CdII centers, which increases the rigidity of (HL)2– and reduces the nonradiative relaxation process (CHEF effect). As shown in , however, the emissions for (HL)2–-bridged 2D polymer 1 and 3D polymer 2, especially for 1, are stronger than those for 1–3D polymers 3–5 built from the mixed ligands (main ligand (HL)2– and auxiliary ligands phen, bpy, and pbim). The obvious difference in the emission intensities for 1–5 could be further explained based on their structures. For the 1–3D polymers 3–5, the mismatching emission spectra of main ligand (HL)2– and auxiliary ligands phen, bpy, and pbim not only broaden the emission bands of 3–5 but also flatten the distribution of the emission intensities. In other words, the excitation light with certain light flux is synchronously absorbed by the main and auxiliary ligands in the resulting complexes, but the emission spectra of the main and auxiliary ligands are not matching as overlaid on each other and thereby broaden the emission bands and reduce the emission intensities in the end. As for the emission intensity of (HL)2–-bridged 3D polymer 2 being greatly weakened in comparison with that of (HL)2–-bridged 2D polymer 1, this may arise from the coordinated water in 2 more easily consuming energy through thermal vibrations than that of the coordinated DMF in 1.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence Properties

The solid-state luminescent properties of cadmium(II) polymers 1-5 were investigated at room temperature (the phase purity was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction as shown in Figures S1-5). Compounds 1-5 all exhibited one emission band centered at 421, 448, 449, 444, and 400 nm upon excitation at 366, 365, 383, 362, and 345 nm, respectively (). In combination with the emission spectra of free ligands H3L, phen, bpy, and pbim (Figures S13 and S14), the emission bands of 1-5 that slightly blue- or red-shift from the 425 nm emission of free ligand H3L can be mainly attributed to the intraligand π-π* transitions of (HL)2- ligands, which can be compared with those emissions reported for cadmium(II) complexes with other N-donor ligands. The differences in the excitation and emission energies for 1-5 are dependent on metal-ligand perturbations and thereby on the coordination geometries of CdII in every compound. Additionally, the relatively broad emission bands for 3-5 indicate some contribution from the intraligand π-π* transitions of the auxiliary ligands phen, bpy, and pbim. On the whole, complexes 1-5 exhibit stronger emission intensities compared to the emission peak of free ligand H3L. The intensity increase of the luminescence for these complexes may be attributed to the chelation of (HL)2- with CdII centers, which increases the rigidity of (HL)2- and reduces the nonradiative relaxation process (CHEF effect). As shown in , however, the emissions for (HL)2--bridged 2D polymer 1 and 3D polymer 2, especially for 1, are stronger than those for 1-3D polymers 3-5 built from the mixed ligands (main ligand (HL)2- and auxiliary ligands phen, bpy, and pbim). The obvious difference in the emission intensities for 1-5 could be further explained based on their structures. For the 1-3D polymers 3-5, the mismatching emission spectra of main ligand (HL)2- and auxiliary ligands phen, bpy, and pbim not only broaden the emission bands of 3-5 but also flatten the distribution of the emission intensities. In other words, the excitation light with certain light flux is synchronously absorbed by the main and auxiliary ligands in the resulting complexes, but the emission spectra of the main and auxiliary ligands are not matching as overlaid on each other and thereby broaden the emission bands and reduce the emission intensities in the end. As for the emission intensity of (HL)2--bridged 3D polymer 2 being greatly weakened in comparison with that of (HL)2--bridged 2D polymer 1, this may arise from the coordinated water in 2 more easily consuming energy through thermal vibrations than that of the coordinated DMF in 1.

elements.content: Five 1–3D cadmium­(II) polymers with architectural diversities and interesting topologies have been successfully synthesized through the traditional evaporation method or hydro/solvothermal methods using H3L ligand or H3L ligand incorporating auxiliary ligands phen, bpy, and pbim, respectively. In those complexes, doubly deprotonated H3L ligands and CdII atoms display versatile coordination modes. Complex 1 is a 2D helical structure with (4·82) topology built up from 3-connected (HL)2– and CdII nodes. Complex 2 containing (HL)2–-bridged tetranuclear CdII subunits is a 3D helical structure where both (HL)2– and CdII adopt three coordination modes to form a rare 3-connected network with (5·8·12)2(5·12·16)2(5·82)­(82·12) topology. Substituting the smaller terminal ligands DMF or water with the larger terminal ligand phen, (HL)2– ligands only use their imidazoledicarboxylates to bis-chelate CdII centers into a zigzag chain structure of 3. Complex 4 is a (3,4)-connected 3D network with (4·82)­(4·82·103) topology built up from the (HL)2–-bridged (4,82) mesolayer observed in 1 being further linked by rodlike bpy bridges replacing terminal ligand DMF. Complex 5 is a (3,4)-connected 2D novel network with (3·4·8)2(3·4·5·82·9)2(32·82·92) topology, consisting of (HL)2–- and pbim-bridged macrocycle chains. As expected, the strongly bis-chelating coordination mode μ-kN,O:kN′,O′ of the imidazoledicarboxylate of (HL)2– absolutely dominates the assemblies with CdII in those complexes. Intriguingly, the additional ligands, such as smaller terminal ligands water and DMF, larger planar terminal ligand phen, as well as rodlike and V-shaped bridges bpy and pbim, exert obvious influence on the coordination modes of ligands (HL)2– and the resulting architectures. Clearly, larger terminal and bridging ligands phen and pbim could limit the coordination of the pyridyl of (HL)2– through steric hindrance. Moreover, the photoluminescence properties of these compounds are significantly influenced by the additional ligands and clearly indicate that the matching emission spectra of main and auxiliary ligands play a key role in the rational design and synthesis for new photoluminescent MOF materials incorporating two or more functional organic ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Five 1-3D cadmium(II) polymers with architectural diversities and interesting topologies have been successfully synthesized through the traditional evaporation method or hydro/solvothermal methods using H3L ligand or H3L ligand incorporating auxiliary ligands phen, bpy, and pbim, respectively. In those complexes, doubly deprotonated H3L ligands and CdII atoms display versatile coordination modes. Complex 1 is a 2D helical structure with (4⋅82) topology built up from 3-connected (HL)2- and CdII nodes. Complex 2 containing (HL)2--bridged tetranuclear CdII subunits is a 3D helical structure where both (HL)2- and CdII adopt three coordination modes to form a rare 3-connected network with (5⋅8⋅12)2(5⋅12⋅16)2(5⋅82)(82⋅12) topology. Substituting the smaller terminal ligands DMF or water with the larger terminal ligand phen, (HL)2- ligands only use their imidazoledicarboxylates to bis-chelate CdII centers into a zigzag chain structure of 3. Complex 4 is a (3,4)-connected 3D network with (4⋅82)(4⋅82⋅103) topology built up from the (HL)2--bridged (4,82) mesolayer observed in 1 being further linked by rodlike bpy bridges replacing terminal ligand DMF. Complex 5 is a (3,4)-connected 2D novel network with (3⋅4⋅8)2(3⋅4⋅5⋅82⋅9)2(32⋅82⋅92) topology, consisting of (HL)2-- and pbim-bridged macrocycle chains. As expected, the strongly bis-chelating coordination mode μ-kN,O:kN',O' of the imidazoledicarboxylate of (HL)2- absolutely dominates the assemblies with CdII in those complexes. Intriguingly, the additional ligands, such as smaller terminal ligands water and DMF, larger planar terminal ligand phen, as well as rodlike and V-shaped bridges bpy and pbim, exert obvious influence on the coordination modes of ligands (HL)2- and the resulting architectures. Clearly, larger terminal and bridging ligands phen and pbim could limit the coordination of the pyridyl of (HL)2- through steric hindrance. Moreover, the photoluminescence properties of these compounds are significantly influenced by the additional ligands and clearly indicate that the matching emission spectra of main and auxiliary ligands play a key role in the rational design and synthesis for new photoluminescent MOF materials incorporating two or more functional organic ligands.

Upon evaporating the filtrate at room temperature without disturbance for 4 weeks, colorless block crystals were obtained, washed with methanol, and dried in air, resulting in 34% yield (based on Cd). Anal. Calcd for C13H11BrCdN4O5 (%): C, 31.51; H, 2.24; N, 11.31. Found: C, 31.64; H, 2.26; N, 11.25. A mixture of Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (0.0154 g, 0.05 mmol), H3L (0.0156 g, 0.05 mmol), NaOH (0.0040 g, 0.1 mmol), and deionized H2O (7 mL) was sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave and heated at 150 °C for 72 h. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C h–1, colorless block crystals were obtained, washed with distilled water, and dried in air, resulting in 48% yield (based on Cd). cln_elements.content: The phase purities of the as-synthesized crystalline products 1–5 were determined by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements. As shown in Figures S1–5, the calculated PXRD patterns from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data are in good agreement with the observed ones, indicating phase purity of the polycrystalline samples. Thermal stability of these complexes was investigated by the TGA technique (Figure S6). The TGA curves of 1 and 2 are similar. They began to undergo weight losses at 125 and 120 °C, respectively. With heating, they suffered continuous weight losses until reaching 770 and 630 °C, respectively. The resulting residues of 26.34% for 1 and 28.45% for 2 are presumed to be CdO (calcd 25.91 and 28.57% for 1 and 2, respectively). Compounds 3 and 4 are stable up to 327 and 267 °C, respectively. As overtaken by their heat-resistant temperatures, the samples of 3 and 4 suffered continuous decomposition processes. In the crucibles, the remains of 22.07% for 3 and 24.73% for 4 may be CdO (calcd 22.49 and 25.65% for 3 and 4, respectively). The dehydration process of 5 occurred from 85 to 135 °C, and a further continuous weight loss followed from 178 to 715 °C with the resulting residue of 21.79% perhaps being CdO (calcd 22.21%).

Thermal stability of these complexes was investigated by the TGA technique (Figure S6). The TGA curves of 1 and 2 are similar. They began to undergo weight losses at 125 and 120 °C, respectively. With heating, they suffered continuous weight losses until reaching 770 and 630 °C, respectively. The resulting residues of 26.34% for 1 and 28.45% for 2 are presumed to be CdO (calcd 25.91 and 28.57% for 1 and 2, respectively). Compounds 3 and 4 are stable up to 327 and 267 °C, respectively. As overtaken by their heat-resistant temperatures, the samples of 3 and 4 suffered continuous decomposition processes. In the crucibles, the remains of 22.07% for 3 and 24.73% for 4 may be CdO (calcd 22.49 and 25.65% for 3 and 4, respectively). The dehydration process of 5 occurred from 85 to 135 °C, and a further continuous weight loss followed from 178 to 715 °C with the resulting residue of 21.79% perhaps being CdO (calcd 22.21%).
